tackle.name: Buzzbait
tackle.tip:
Buzzbaits

Cast out, let the bait fall a bit, then reel in to generate vibration just under the surface of the water. Not necessary, but helpful to add a trailer to bladed jigs and chatterbaits.

tackle.name: Lipless Crankbait
tackle.tip:
Crankbaits

Cast out, reel in to dive and generate motion and sound. You can also pull up with the rod to crank up and wobble aggressively.

tackle.name: Spoon
tackle.tip:
Spoons, spinnerbaits, and spinners

Cast out, let the bait fall a bit, then jerk up and/or reel in to imitate fish.

tackle.name: Wacky Rig
tackle.tip:
Wacky Rig

Rig a Senko or similar stick worm on a 1/0 hook, hooked through the middle of the worm perpendicular to the hook. Cast it out just like that, no additional tackle required. Let it fall to the bottom, then pull it up and reel in the slack. Repeat as often as necessary. Bites usually occur on the fall.

tackle.name: Deep-Diving Crankbait
tackle.tip:
Crankbaits

Cast out, reel in to dive and generate motion and sound. You can also pull up with the rod to crank up and wobble aggressively.

tackle.name: Inline Spinner
tackle.tip:
Spoons, spinnerbaits, and spinners

Cast out, let the bait fall a bit, then jerk up and/or reel in to imitate fish.

tackle.name: Crickhopper
tackle.tip:
Crickhopper

Cast out, let the water calm, then start to jerk for popping or reel in to sink and wobble. Start slow to prevent spooking the fish, then speed up as needed. Can fish like a popper or like a crankbait.

tackle.name: Carolina Rig
tackle.tip:
Carolina Rig

An alternative to a fixed bobber rig, when you are trying to find the fish and want to fish closer to the bottom. You can hook live bait or soft plastics on this. Cast out, wait a bit, move it a little bit, and keep the line taut.

tackle.name: Popper
tackle.tip:
Poppers and other noisy topwater lures

Cast out, let the water calm, then start to jerk or reel in to generate the action. Start slow to prevent spooking the fish, then speed up as needed.

tackle.name: Frog
tackle.tip:
Topwater Frogs

Cast out onto lily pads, let the water calm, then start to jerk or hop. Start slow to prevent spooking the fish, then speed up as needed.

tackle.name: Fish Finder Rig
tackle.tip:
Fish Finder Rig

Load this up with any type of cut bait and cast it as far as you can. Keep the line taut and place it in a beach spike as you wait for a big hit. Let the fish peel your drag a bit before setting the hook hard.

tackle.name: Fish Finder Float Rig
tackle.tip:
Fish Finder Float Rig

Keeping the pests away for mid-sized fish, adding a float keeps your bait elevated. Great for jetties and piers that get you out further. This is a good evening shark rig as it keeps away from the rays.

tackle.name: Bottom Rig
tackle.tip:
Bottom Rig

Great for rocky bottoms or turbulent surf, use this to catch smaller surf species on the beach, piers, jetties, and inlets. Cast over the first break in the surf or keep close to pylons and rocks when fishing platforms. Keep line taut and monitor small bites as heavier weight leaves no give for small fish.

tackle.name: Whopper Plopper
tackle.tip:
Poppers and other noisy topwater lures

Cast out, let the water calm, then start to jerk or reel in to generate the action. Start slow to prevent spooking the fish, then speed up as needed.

tackle.name: Chatterbait
tackle.tip:
Chatterbaits, Hard Swimbaits, and Bladed Jigs

Cast out, let the bait fall a bit, then jerk up and/or reel in to imitate fish. Not necessary, but helpful to add a trailer to bladed jigs and chatterbaits.

tackle.name: Bladed Jig
tackle.tip:
Chatterbaits, Hard Swimbaits, and Bladed Jigs

Cast out, let the bait fall a bit, then jerk up and/or reel in to imitate fish. Not necessary, but helpful to add a trailer to bladed jigs and chatterbaits.

tackle.name: Spinnerbait
tackle.tip:
Spoons, spinnerbaits, and spinners

Cast out, let the bait fall a bit, then jerk up and/or reel in to imitate fish.

tackle.name: Topwater Prop Bait
tackle.tip:
Poppers and other noisy topwater lures

Cast out, let the water calm, then start to jerk or reel in to generate the action. Start slow to prevent spooking the fish, then speed up as needed.

tackle.name: Swimbait
tackle.tip:
Chatterbaits, Hard Swimbaits, and Bladed Jigs

Cast out, let the bait fall a bit, then jerk up and/or reel in to imitate fish. Not necessary, but helpful to add a trailer to bladed jigs and chatterbaits.

tackle.name: Shallow-Diving Crankbait
tackle.tip:
Crankbaits

Cast out, reel in to dive and generate motion and sound. You can also pull up with the rod to crank up and wobble aggressively.

tackle.name: Jerkbait
tackle.tip:
Jerkbaits

Cast out, let the bait fall a bit, then reel in or simply jerk to generate the action. Slow down or speed up depending on the need.

tackle.name: Suspended Jerkbait
tackle.tip:
Jerkbaits

Cast out, let the bait fall a bit, then reel in or simply jerk to generate the action. Slow down or speed up depending on the need.
